Main Content: Information for foreign national candidates All Guide and Brochures Information for foreign national candidates The demand for H-1B visas rises each year. Yet, the odds of being selected for the H-1B lottery are less than 25%. The Build Fellowship offers a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution with a 99% acceptance rate, allowing foreign national talent – like yourself – to pursue careers in the fastest-growing industries across the U.S. If you are a foreign national who wants to work, or continue working, in the U.S., securing your visa is a top priority — The Build Fellowship is here to help. Qualification & Commitment Candidate Qualifications A Bachelor's degree or equivalent work experience in a specialized field. Ability to dedicate 5+ hours per week to educational programming initiatives and workforce development. A benefactor (a company, organization, or individual) willing to support the Fellowship costs – Fellows cannot fund their own Fellowship. Fellowship Commitment Applications are accepted on a rolling basis throughout the year, Fellowships can begin at any time. Fellows are sponsored for cap-exempt H-1Bs for up to 3 years, with a minimum 12 month commitment. A 3 year extension is possible. Step 1: Application The Build Fellowship welcomes applications from foreign national innovators, experts, and entrepreneurs seeking immigration solutions for U.S. employment. Step 2: Placement The Build Fellowship places top candidates in part-time positions at our partner Nonprofits and Universities. Step 3: Employment By working part-time for partner organizations, Build Fellows secure their cap-exempt H-1B visa, allowing them to be employed full time at U.S. companies. Key Benefits & Responsibilities Visa Sponsorship & Support The Build Fellowship offers ongoing immigration support and guidance to Build Fellows, while sponsoring them for their part-time cap-exempt H-1B visas. This enables benefactors to file a full time cap-exempt H-1B visa concurrently. Company Benefits The Build Fellowship offers companies work visa solutions for their top foreign nationals and access to a pipeline of incoming talent trained with relevant skills and industry knowledge. University Benefits Build Fellows launch projects for partner university and college students, offering industry knowledge and skills development to build the U.S. workforce through educational programming. Part-Time, Remote Employment Fellows work 5+ hours per week launching projects and educational programming at partner universities to develop students’ skills and knowledge and prepare them for the future workforce. 1:1 lecture and mentorship sessions Experiential learning projects in your specialized field Hours are flexible and based on Fellow schedules Application to Acceptance Timeline Evaluation & Contracting 2–3 week Nomination & Consultation Screening & H-1B Evaluation Contract Signed Visa Processing 6-8 Week Petition Development Visa Approved (if no RFE) Employment Starts 1 Week Fellowship Begins Full-Time Employer Files Petition The Build Fellowship Pricing Model. Build & Company Employ the Fellow‍ Company pays Build $4000 per month‍ Fellow is employed by Build & the Company, both entities manage the immigration needs Build employs the foreign national in the Fellowship for 5 hours per week and sponsors them for a part-time, cap-exempt H-1B visa. Company employs the foreign national and sponsors them for a full-time, concurrent H-1B visa. H-4 dependent filings. FAQs What are the required documents to apply? Job Description Resume / Curriculum Vitae Degree Transcripts Diplomas Certified Academic Evaluation What if my degree was obtained outside of the United States? Before applying to The Build Fellowship, any degree obtained outside of the U.S. should be evaluated and certified by a credential verification service. We recommend Park Evaluations for a quick and cost-effective service. Visit https://parkeval.com/build-fellowship-online-request-form/ to submit your request. Do I need to be in the United States to apply? No, you do not need to be in the U.S. to apply. However, you will need to visit the U.S. Embassy or Consulate in your home country and apply for an H-1B visa. Once you enter the U.S. in H-1B status, you would begin your employment with The Build Fellowship. How is the salary share calculated? The salary share is calculated according to the fair prevailing wage for a Fellow’s specialty occupation and wage level within the city and state in which the Fellow resides, for 5 hours per week of work using the FLC Data Center. In addition to the salary, which is remitted to the Fellow, there are costs for taxes, software, and Fees. These fees are invoiced quarterly and are approximately $350 and 20.65% of the quarterly salary share. How long does the entire process take? Processing times vary, but generally will take about 2 to 3 months. Can my family accompany me? Yes, your spouse and children under the age of 21 can accompany you under the H-4 visa category. Main Content: Become a Build Fellowship nonprofit partner All Guide and Brochures Become a Build Fellowship nonprofit partner The demand for H-1B visas rises each year. Yet, the odds of a foreign national being selected by the annual H-1B visa lottery is less than 25%. The Build Fellowship offers a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution, with a 99% acceptance rate, allowing foreign national talent to pursue careers in the fastest-growing industries across the U.S. The Build Fellowship offers a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution, with a 99% acceptance rate, allowing foreign national talent to pursue careers in the fastest-growing industries across the U.S. The Build Fellowship Overview & First Steps Key Points The Build Fellowship team evaluates and petitions foreign national employment to nonprofit and university partners. Nonprofit partners employ Build Fellows part-time, for approximately 5 hours per week. Fellows with part-time, cap–exempt H-1B status through The Build Fellowship can have a full-time employer file a concurrent capexempt H-1B visa. The Build Fellowship is responsible for the administrative and compliance components of the program, making it easy for nonprofit partners to launch Build Fellowships without additional capacity. The Build Fellowship can launch programs that fit the unique needs of your organization. From a 2-person program to a 1,000 person program, we are able to tailor our efforts to your goals. Step 1: Application The Build Fellowship welcomes applications from foreign national innovators, experts, and entrepreneurs seeking immigration solutions for U.S. employment. Step 2: Placement Top candidates are places in part- time positions at out partner nonprofits and universities. Step 3: Employment By working part-time for partner organizations, Build Fellows secure their cap-exempt H-1B visa, allowing them to be employed full time at U.S. companies. The Build Fellowship & Nonprofit Relationship Roles & Responsibilities Every organization that The Build Fellowship partners with will have its own mission and programmatic goals. The Build Fellowship manages operations, immigration legal processes, and compliance needs, allowing you to stay focused on achieving your mission. The role of partner organizations is to run their program effectively by leveraging the expertise of part-time foreign national employees. Companies are responsible for paying program fees. The Build Fellowship covers the partner’s cost of employing the foreign national and provides a stipend to support the operational cost of running the partnership program. Build’s Partnership Program provides your organization with the infrastructure, technology, and compliance to run a best-in-class program. Fellowship application management software Program administration and compliance Foreign national evaluation and placement Coordination with immigration attorneys Coordination with concurrent employer Liaising for University partnerships Education program support and tools HR, recruitment, and hiring support Microsite development and management Marketing and communications toolkit The two types of Build Fellowships that nonprofit partners can provide. Standard Build Fellowship Program The standard, turnkey education program offered to partners, administered by The Build Fellowship team, with minimal inputs required of the partner organization. Fellows offer students at partner institutions access to world-class subject matter training through accessible educational materials and 1:1 sessions. Custom Build Fellowship Programs Custom programs are administered by nonprofit partners themselves and must be approved of and meet minimum compliance requirements defined by Build. These programs may take many forms, such as the micro-internship program offered by Open Avenues Foundation. The Build Fellowship Pricing Model. Build & Company Employ the Fellow Company pays Build $4000 per month Fellow is employed by Build & the Company, both entities manage the immigration needs Build employs the foreign national in the Fellowship for 5 hours per week and sponsors them for a part-time, cap-exempt H-1B visa. Company employs the foreign national and sponsors them for a full-time, concurrent H-1B visa. H-4 dependent filings. Ability to dedicate 5+ hours per week to educational programming initiatives and workforce development. A benefactor willing to support the costs of the Fellowship – Fellows cannot fund their own Fellowship. Fellowship Commitment Applications are accepted on a rolling basis throughout the year, Fellowships can begin at any time. Fellows are sponsored for cap-exempt H-1Bs for up to 3 years, with a 12 month minimum commitment. A 3 year extension is possible. Download the brochure Request more information Looking for more? Main Content: Cap exempt H-1B visa sponsorship & how to talk with your benefactor All Guide and Brochures Cap exempt H-1B visa sponsorship & how to talk with your benefactor The Build Fellowship offers a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution with a 99% acceptance rate, allowing foreign national talent to pursue careers in the fastest-growing industries across the United States. If you are a foreign national who wants to work or continue working in the U.S., securing your visa is a top priority — The Build Fellowship is here to help. Offers an immigration solution for global talent Advances the missions of U.S. colleges, universities, & research institutions Prepares college students across the U.S. for jobs in high-demand fields Fills talent gaps for U.S. companies and increases the competitiveness of the economy at large You will need a benefactor to finance your Fellowship. A Fellow cannot pay for their own Fellowship. There are two primary types of benefactors: U.S. Employers and companies willing to sponsor a candidate’s fellowship Individual benefactors willing to fund a candidate’s fellowship How do I talk to my employer about funding my Fellowship? KEY POINTS TO KEEP IN MIND Sponsorship benefits you, your employer, and the U.S. workforce at large. U.S. companies in the fastest growing industries need access to specialized talent to maintain a competitive edge. Hiring highly-skilled foreign nationals to work full-time at U.S. companies often requires the foreign national to obtain an H-1B visa, however, the annual cap on H-1B visas is a significant barrier. The Build Fellowship’s cap-exempt H-1B visa solution offers an immigration pathway for skilled foreign talent to work full-time in the U.S. without relying on the H-1B lottery. Once Build Fellows are approved for a cap-exempt H-1B and begin the Fellowship, their full-time employer can immediately file a concurrent H-1B outside of the lottery. How your company will benefit Attract top talent Attract the world’s top talent for full-time U.S. employment opportunities through partnering with The Build Fellowship. Retain top talent Retain your current talent by offering visa sponsorship. Build talent pipelines Gain unique access to students trained with relevant industry knowledge entering the workforce Gain employee loyalty Sponsoring builds loyalty and deepens the employee employer relationship. An employee with a work visa sponsored through a company for a specified time is much less likely to leave than another employee who has less incentive to stick around. Promote diversity Hiring employees from other countries enables a company to bring together different perspectives and experiences, promoting diversity within the company. Diverse teams deliver 60% better results and make better decisions in 87% of cases. Find peace of mind Have a back-up plan to the H-1B lottery, so you can forecast your needs accordingly. Employee benefactor sample email 1 Dear EMPLOYER NAME, I hope this email finds you well. I am reaching out about a potential solution to my work visa situation. The Build Fellowship is an organization whose mission is to provide career pathways for everyone, no matter where they are from. They offer a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution for foreign nationals looking to work full-time in the U.S. I would work part-time for approximately 5 hours per week with a nonprofit through The Build Fellowship while also working full-time with COMPANY NAME. During my part-time work as a Build Fellow, I’d work directly with U.S. college and universities to advance the United States education system. The onboarding of new Fellows takes about 6-8 weeks, enabling cap subject companies, such as COMPANY NAME, to file a concurrent H-1B petition for my full-time employment. Companies are responsible for the financial commitment of the Fellowship program. I am attaching the Pricing information from Build. Although I am aware of the significant commitment that comes with this Fellowship, I believe it is the most sustainable solution to my work visa situation. It allows me to work 3 years with the ability to renew for an additional 3 years at COMPANY NAME. Additionally, the skills and experience I will gain from training students and networking with potential candidates for our company will benefit the future of COMPANY NAME as well. If you would like to learn more about The Build Fellowship visit their website here . You can also schedule an initial consultation with The Build Fellowship team here . Let me know if you have any questions. I appreciate your consideration. Best, YOUR NAME Employee benefactor sample email 2 Dear EMPLOYER NAME, I hope this email finds you well. I'm writing to share a promising solution to my work visa situation that offers an alternative to the H-1B lottery, with a 99%+ approval rate. This solution is a cap-exempt H-1B visa, sponsored by The Build Fellowship, that would allow me to continue working full-time at COMPANY NAME. The Build Fellowship is an organization whose mission is to provide career pathways for everyone, no matter where they are from. They offer a cap-exempt H-1B visa for foreign nationals seeking full-time employment in the U.S. like me. This solution allows me to work full time for COMPANY NAME, while working ~5 hours a week on a part-time basis with The Build Fellowship as a Global Talent Fellow. Highlights of The Build Fellowship: Talent Retention: Attract, hire, and retain the world’s top talent to work in the U.S Certainty: 99% approval rate for eligible foreign nationals accepted into The Build Fellowship Speed: ~8-10 weeks total duration, from process start until concurrent H-1B is approved Timing: Employee can start working full-time immediately once concurrent H-1B is received by USCIS To join the Fellowship, you, as the employer, would need to nominate me for this opportunity. The Build Fellowship offers a free initial consultation to assess the probability of a successful approval before entering any contract. See this info session from the founder and CEO, Danielle Goldman, for a detailed overview, including benefits, next steps, and costs. Although I am aware of the significant commitment that comes with this Fellowship, it would allow me to continue to work at COMPANY NAME for 3 years with the ability to renew for an additional 3 years. The skills and experience I will gain from training students and networking with potential candidates will benefit the future of COMPANY NAME as well. You can learn more about The Build Fellowship at buildfellowship.com . You can also schedule an initial consultation with The Build Fellowship team here . Let me know if you have any questions. I appreciate your consideration. Best, YOUR NAME How do I talk to an individual benefactor about funding my Fellowship? KEY POINTS TO KEEP IN MIND Securing a U.S. work visa is difficult, even for highly skilled foreign nationals who studied areas in STEM and business who qualify for the H-1B visa are rarely accepted due to a randomized lottery. Last year – only 24% of applicants were selected. The Build Fellowship is a program that will allow me to live and work in the U.S. through securing a cap-exempt H-1B visa. Fellows work ~5 hours a week for The Build Fellowship’s nonprofit partners advancing the U.S. education system training students. Once a foreign national’s Build Fellowship starts, they are then eligible to work full-time for a U.S. company, making hiring the foreign national more appealing. The Fellowship lasts a minimum of twelve months and up to three years. An additional three year extension is possible. Individual benefactor sample email Dear NAME OF INDIVIDUAL BENEFACTOR, I hope this email finds you well. I'm writing to share a promising solution to my work visa situation that would enable me to work and live in the U.S. This solution is a cap-exempt H-1B visa through The Build Fellowship. The Build Fellowship is an organization whose mission is to provide career pathways for everyone, no matter where they are from. They offer a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution for foreign nationals like me. If accepted, I would work part-time with The Build Fellowship’s nonprofit partners as a Fellow, allowing me to live in the U.S. and pursue full-time employment opportunities for up to three years, with the opportunity to apply for an additional three-year extension. My work as a Fellow directly advances the U.S. education system, where I would train and mentor students in my area of expertise. Joining The Build Fellowship would also make me significantly more appealing to potential employers, highlighting my capabilities in my field. To join the Fellowship, you, as the individual benefactor, would need to fund me for this opportunity. See this info session video for a detailed overview, including benefits, next steps, and costs. I have provided a snapshot with a more detailed breakdown of the costs below. While I understand this is a significant financial commitment, I believe that joining The Build Fellowship is critical to my success in the U.S. The skills and experience I will gain from training students and networking will benefit my future and improve my chances of being hired by a best-in-class employer. If you would like to learn more you can visit buildfellowship.com . Let me know if you have any questions. I appreciate your consideration. Best, YOUR NAME Download the brochure Request more information Looking for more? Request more information Looking for more? Request more information Looking for more? Main Content: Information for foreign nationals candidates All Guide and Brochures Information for foreign nationals candidates The demand for H-1B visas rises each year. Yet, the odds of being selected for the H-1B lottery are less than 25%. The Build Fellowship offers a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution with a 99% acceptance rate, allowing foreign national talent –like yourself – to pursue careers in the fastest-growing industries across the U.S. If you are a foreign national who wants to work, or continue working, in the U.S., securing your visa is a top priority —The Build Fellowship is here to help. Key Benefits & Responsibilities Visa sponsorship & support The Build Fellowship offers ongoing immigration support and guidance to Build Fellows, while sponsoring them for their part-time cap-exempt H-1B visas. This enables benefactors to file a full-time cap-exempt H-1B visa concurrently. Company benefits The Build Fellowship offers companies work visa solutions for their top foreign nationals and access to a pipeline of incoming talent trained with relevant skills and industry knowledge. University benefits Build Fellows launch projects for partner university and college students, offering industry knowledge and skills development to build the U.S. workforce through educational programming. Part-time, remote employment Fellows work 5 hours per week launching projects and educational programming at partner universities to develop students' skills and knowledge and prepare them for the future workforce. 1:1 lecture and mentorship sessions Experiential learning projects in your specialized field Hours are flexible and based on Fellow schedules Download the brochure Request more information Looking for more? Page Title: Individual benefactor sample email
H1: Individual benefactor sample email
All Headings: H1: Individual benefactor sample email
Main Content: Individual benefactor sample email All Guide and Brochures Individual benefactor sample email Dear NAME OF INDIVIDUAL BENEFACTOR, I hope this email finds you well. I'm writing to share a promising solution to my work visa situation that would enable me to work and live in the U.S. This solution is a cap-exempt H-1B visa through The Build Fellowship. The Build Fellowship is an organization whose mission is to provide career pathways for everyone, no matter where they are from. They offer a cap-exempt H-1B visa solution for foreign nationals like me. If accepted, I would work part-time with The Build Fellowship's nonprofit partners as a Fellow, allowing me to live in the U.S. and pursue full-time employment opportunities for up to three years, with the opportunity to apply for an additional three-year extension. My work as a Fellow directly advances the U.S. education system, where I would train and mentor students in my area of expertise. Joining The Build Fellowship would also make me significantly more appealing to potential employers, highlighting my capabilities in my field. To join the Fellowship, you, as the individual benefactor, would need to fund me for this opportunity. See this info session video for a detailed overview, including benefits, next steps, and costs. I have provided a snapshot with a more detailed breakdown of the costs below. While I understand this is a significant financial commitment, I believe that joining The Build Fellowship is critical to my success in the U.S. The skills and experience I will gain from training students and networking will benefit my future and improve my chances of being hired by a best-in-class employer. If you would like to learn more you can visit buildfellowship.com . Let me know if you have any questions. I appreciate your consideration. Best, YOUR NAME Download the brochure Request more information Looking for more? Request more information Looking for more? Request more information Looking for more? Main Content: How do I talk to an individual benefactor about funding my Fellowship? All Guide and Brochures How do I talk to an individual benefactor about funding my Fellowship? Key points to keep in mind Securing a U.S. work visa is difficult, even for highly skilled foreign nationals who studied areas in STEM and business who qualify for the H-1B visa are rarely accepted due to a randomized lottery. Last year – only 24% of applicants were selected. The Build Fellowship is a program that will allow me to live and work in the U.S. through securing a cap-exempt H-1B visa. Fellows work ~5 hours a week for The Build Fellowship's nonprofit partners advancing the U.S. education system training students. Once a foreign national's Build Fellowship starts, they are then eligible to work full-time for a U.S. company, making hiring the foreign national more appealing. The Fellowship lasts a minimum of twelve months and up to three years. An additional three year extension is possible. Download the brochure Request more information Looking for more? Main Content:
Information for companies looking to sponsor their global talent All Guide and Brochures Information for companies looking to sponsor their global talent U.S. companies in the fastest-growing industries need access to specialized talent to maintain a competitive edge. Yet the odds of a foreign national being accepted by the annual H-1B visa lottery are less than 25%. The Build Fellowship's cap-exempt H-1B visa solution offers an immigration pathway to skilled global talent, with a 99% acceptance rate, without relying on the H-1B lottery. Build Fellows are employed part-time by Build Fellowship nonprofit and University partners, enabling them to work full-time for U.S. companies – like yours. The Build Fellowship Overview: Eligibility & Commitment Fellow Eligibility A Bachelor's degree or equivalent work experience in a specialized field. Ability to dedicate 5+ hours per week to educational programming initiatives and workforce development. A benefactor (a company, organization, or individual) willing to support the Fellowship costs – Fellows cannot fund their own Fellowship. Fellowship Commitment Applications are accepted on a rolling basis throughout the year, Fellowships can begin at any time. Fellows are sponsored for cap-exempt H-1Bs for up to 3 years, with a minimum 12 month commitment. A 3 year extension is possible. Step 1: Application The Build Fellowship welcomes applications from foreign national innovators, experts, and entrepreneurs seeking immigration solutions for U.S. employment. Step 2: Placement The Build Fellowship places top candidates in part-time positions at our partner Nonprofits and Universities. Step 3: Employment By working part-time for partner organizations, Build Fellows secure their cap-exempt H-1B visa, allowing them to be employed full time at U.S. companies. Key Benefits for Companies Visa Sponsorship & Support The Build Fellowship offers ongoing immigration support and guidance to Build Fellows, while sponsoring them for their part-time cap-exempt H-1B visas. This enables company benefactors to file a full-time cap-exempt H-1B visa concurrently. Peace of Mind Gain peace of mind knowing you have a back up plan to the H-1B lottery, so you can forecast and plan your staff needs accordingly. Talent Pipelines Gain unique access to students entering the workforce who are trained with relevant industry knowledge. Part-Time, Remote Employment Fellows work 5+ hours per week launching projects and educational programming at partner universities to develop students' skills and knowledge and prepare them for the future workforce. 1:1 lecture and mentorship sessions Experiential learning projects in your specialized field Hours are flexible and based on Fellow schedules Application to Acceptance Timeline Evaluation & Contracting 2–3 week Nomination & Consultation Screening & H-1B Evaluation Contract Signed Visa Processing 6-8 Week Petition Development Visa Approved (if no RFE) Employment Starts 1 Week Fellowship Begins Full-Time Employer Files Petition The Build Fellowship Pricing Model. Build & Company Employ the Fellow Company pays Build $4000 per month Fellow is employed by Build & the Company, both entities manage the immigration needs Build employs the foreign national in the Fellowship
for 5 hours per week and sponsors them for a part-time, cap-exempt H-1B visa. Company employs the foreign national and sponsors
them for a full-time, concurrent H-1B visa. H-4 dependent filings. Download the brochure Request more information Looking for more? Request more information Looking for more? Page Title: How do I talk to my employer about funding my Fellowship?
H1: How do I talk to my employer about funding my Fellowship?
All Headings:
H1: How do I talk to my employer about funding my Fellowship?
H3: Key points to keep in mind
H2: How your company will benefit
H3: Attract top talent
H3: Retain top talent
H3: Build talent pipelines
H3: Gain employee loyalty
H3: Promote diversity
H3: Find peace of mind
Main Content: How do I talk to my employer about funding my Fellowship? All Guide and Brochures How do I talk to my employer about funding my Fellowship? Key points to keep in mind Sponsorship benefits you, your employer, and the U.S. workforce at large. U.S. companies in the fastest growing industries need access to specialized talent to maintain a competitive edge. Hiring highly-skilled foreign nationals to work full-time at U.S. companies often requires the foreign national to obtain an H-1B visa, however, the annual cap on H-1B visas is a significant barrier. The Build Fellowship's cap-exempt H-1B visa solution offers an immigration pathway for skilled foreign talent to work full-time in the U.S. without relying on the H-1B lottery. Once Build Fellows are approved for a cap-exempt H-1B and begin the Fellowship, their full-time employer can immediately file a concurrent H-1B outside of the lottery. How your company will benefit Attract top talent Attract the world's top talent for full-time U.S. employment opportunities through partnering with The Build Fellowship. Retain top talent Retain your current talent by offering visa sponsorship. Build talent pipelines Gain unique access to students trained with relevant industry knowledge entering the workforce. Gain employee loyalty Sponsoring builds loyalty and deepens the employee employer relationship. An employee with a work visa sponsored through a company for a specified time is much less likely to leave than another employee who has less incentive to stick around. Promote diversity Hiring employees from other countries enables a company to bring together different perspectives and experiences, promoting diversity within the company. Diverse teams deliver 60% better results and make better decisions in 87% of cases [1] . Find peace of mind Have a back-up plan to the H-1B lottery, so you can forecast your needs accordingly. Page Title: What is The Build Fellowship?
Meta Description: The Build Fellowship by Open Avenues is a nationwide, cap-exempt H-1B visa fellowship offered to foreign nationals who qualify for an H-1B visa in the United...
H1: What is The Build Fellowship?
All Headings: H1: What is The Build Fellowship?
Main Content: What is The Build Fellowship? All resources What is The Build Fellowship? The Build Fellowship by Open Avenues is a nationwide, cap-exempt H-1B visa fellowship offered to foreign nationals who qualify for an H-1B visa in the United States. Fellows obtain a cap-exempt H-1B visa with a Build Fellowship non-profit partner, for whom they are employed 5 or more hours per week and provide mission-advancing work through The Build Fellowship’s programming. Build Fellows contribute to the social and economic success of the U.S. by working with non-profit partners across the country to offer best-in-class research, published content, 1-on-1 instructional sessions, and guidance to students and the public at large, covering critical knowledge areas ranging from computer science to molecular biology. Page Title: What is an H-1B visa?
Meta Description: The H-1B visa is a non-immigrant visa that allows companies in the United States to employ foreign workers in specialty occupations that require theoretical ...
H1: What is an H-1B visa?
All Headings: H1: What is an H-1B visa?
Main Content: What is an H-1B visa? All resources What is an H-1B visa? The H-1B visa is a non-immigrant visa that allows companies in the United States to employ foreign workers in specialty occupations that require theoretical or technical expertise in specialized fields such as in IT, finance, accounting, architecture, engineering, mathematics, science, medicine, etc. It is one of the most common visa types for foreign workers in the U.S. due to its applicability to a wide range of professional occupations. Page Title: What is a cap-exempt H-1B?
Meta Description: The cap-exempt H-1B visa category allows certain U.S. employers to sponsor foreign nationals for H-1B visas without being subject to the annual H-1B numerica...
H1: What is a cap-exempt H-1B?
All Headings: H1: What is a cap-exempt H-1B?
Main Content: What is a cap-exempt H-1B? All resources What is a cap-exempt H-1B? The cap-exempt H-1B visa category allows certain U.S. employers to sponsor foreign nationals for H-1B visas without being subject to the annual H-1B numerical limitations, commonly known as the H-1B cap. Unlike the regular H-1B category, which is limited by an annual quota set by the U.S. government, the cap-exempt category does not have a numerical limit and can accept applications year-round. Page Title: What is the basis for the cap-subject organization to be eligible for cap-exempt concurrent employment?
Meta Description: It is through concurrent employment under 8 CFR 214.2(h)(8)(ii)(F)(6). 8 CFR 214.2(h)(8)(ii)(F)(6) specifically states that the two jobs can be lower than fu...
H1: What is the basis for the cap-subject organization to be eligible for cap-exempt concurrent employment?
All Headings: H1: What is the basis for the cap-subject organization to be eligible for cap-exempt concurrent employment?
Main Content: What is the basis for the cap-subject organization to be eligible for cap-exempt concurrent employment? All resources What is the basis for the cap-subject organization to be eligible for cap-exempt concurrent employment? It is through concurrent employment under 8 CFR 214.2(h)(8)(ii)(F)(6). 8 CFR 214.2(h)(8)(ii)(F)(6) specifically states that the two jobs can be lower than full time or more than full time, as long as “the beneficiary can reasonably and concurrently perform the work described in each employer’s respective petitions”. (6) Concurrent H-1B employment in a cap-subject position of an alien that qualifies for an exemption under section 214(g)(5)(A) or (B) of the Act shall not subject the alien to the numerical limitations in section 214(g)(1)(A) of the Act. When petitioning for concurrent cap-subject H-1B employment, the petitioner must demonstrate that the H-1B beneficiary is employed in valid H-1B status under a cap exemption under section 214(g)(5)(A) or (B) of the Act, the beneficiary's employment with the cap-exempt employer is expected to continue after the new cap-subject petition is approved, and the beneficiary can reasonably and concurrently perform the work described in each employer's respective positions. Page Title: How does this enable companies to sponsor a cap-exempt H-1B for talent?
Meta Description: Once an individual is approved and working for a cap-exempt organization, a new cap-subject employer can file a petition for concurrent H-1B employment at an...
H1: How does this enable companies to sponsor a cap-exempt H-1B for talent?
All Headings: H1: How does this enable companies to sponsor a cap-exempt H-1B for talent?
Main Content: How does this enable companies to sponsor a cap-exempt H-1B for talent? All resources How does this enable companies to sponsor a cap-exempt H-1B for talent? Once an individual is approved and working for a cap-exempt organization, a new cap-subject employer can file a petition for concurrent H-1B employment at any time and does not have to go through the H-1B lottery process. The employee can start working for the new H-1B cap-subject employer upon the receipt of the H-1B petition. This is called H-1B portability. As soon as Build Fellows are approved for a cap-exempt H-1B and start their fellowship, their full-time employer (typically subject to the annual lottery) can immediately file an H-1B for them concurrently. Page Title: Who is the H-1B petitioner?
Meta Description: The Build Fellowship’s nonprofit partners serve as the petitioners for cap-exempt petitions for 5 hours per week, and the full-time employer is the petitione...
H1: Who is the H-1B petitioner?
All Headings: H1: Who is the H-1B petitioner?
Main Content: Who is the H-1B petitioner? All resources Who is the H-1B petitioner? The Build Fellowship’s nonprofit partners serve as the petitioners for cap-exempt petitions for 5 hours per week, and the full-time employer is the petitioner for the full-time concurrent employment. As for the timeline, the nonprofit partner’s cap-exempt petition is filed first. On the Build Fellow’s first day, an approval notice and employment verification letter are shared with the employer to include in the concurrent cap-exempt filing, to demonstrate employment with the cap-exempt organization. Main Content: H-1B RFE (Request for Evidence) Rates Are Climbing Under Trump – The Build Fellowship Blog immigration-news H-1B RFE (Request for Evidence) Rates Are Climbing Under Trump March 10, 2025 | 7 min read H-1B RFE (Request for Evidence) Rates Are Climbing Under Trump Daniel Kwik, Director of Marketing & Technology Freepik Table of Content What is an RFE? RFE Rates Are Climbing — Here’s What We Are Experiencing On The Ground. How Trump’s 2025 Re-Election is Driving RFE Increases How Presidential Power Shapes RFEs Trump’s Record and What It Means for 2025 RFEs Why Do Applicants Receive RFEs? Common Triggers for RFEs What Does an RFE Look Like? Step-by-Step Guide to Responding to an RFE 1. Read It Thoroughly — and Break It Down 2. Gather Documents (and Extra Evidence) 3. Organize Your Response 4. Consult with an Immigration Attorney 5. Respond Early Tips for Avoiding RFEs Special Considerations for H-1B Applicants What Happens if You Ignore an RFE? Can You Get More Than One RFE? Conclusion: RFE Readiness Is Key in 2025 Share: If you’re a foreign national or employer navigating the U.S. immigration process, you’ve likely heard of the term RFE , short for Request for Evidence . In 2025, RFEs are more than just a minor inconvenience — they’ve become a major checkpoint in the immigration journey , particularly for employment-based visas like the H-1B. What is an RFE? An RFE (Request for Evidence) is a formal request from U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) asking for additional documents or clarification before they can approve or deny an immigration petition. It’s important to stress: An RFE is not a denial. It simply means USCIS needs more proof to make a decision. However, if handled poorly — or ignored — it could easily lead to a denial. RFE Rates Are Climbing — Here’s What We Are Experiencing On The Ground. At The Build Fellowship , our immigration team actively tracks the petitions we help support, and we are already seeing a sharp increase in RFE rates in 2025 (as of March 5, 2025) - increasing 23 percentage points since 2024. This sharp increase aligns with broader political trends. Immigration attorneys and employers are reporting heightened scrutiny from USCIS, particularly around specialty occupation classifications , employer-employee relationships , and degree qualifications for foreign nationals. How Trump’s 2025 Re-Election is Driving RFE Increases One of the clearest drivers behind the spike in RFEs in 2025 is the re-election of Donald Trump . Based on Trump’s immigration stance during his first term (2017-2021) and early executive actions since returning to office in January 2025, immigration policy has once again shifted toward increased enforcement and heightened scrutiny — especially in employment-based immigration. How Presidential Power Shapes RFEs The President doesn’t directly issue RFEs , but the executive branch oversees USCIS , which is part of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The President appoints the DHS Secretary and the USCIS Director , both of whom have enormous discretion over: Setting adjudication standards for visa petitions. Issuing policy memoranda that influence how officers evaluate cases. Creating internal training materials that guide RFE triggers. Prioritizing worksite enforcement , which indirectly influences how strictly petitions are reviewed. Trump’s Record and What It Means for 2025 RFEs During Trump’s first term, RFEs skyrocketed, especially for H-1B petitions. This was no accident — his administration issued policy memos encouraging USCIS officers to: Apply stricter standards to specialty occupation determinations . Heavily scrutinize third-party placements (common in IT consulting). Question the validity of degree equivalency evaluations from certain providers. Make it easier for officers to issue RFEs instead of approvals when they had any doubt about eligibility. Here’s some data we put together to demonstrate the disparity in historical rates of RFEs between the Trump administration vs the Biden administration on RFEs. As shown in the chart, the average RFE rate under the Trump administration (2017-2020) was on average 20-40 percentage points higher than the Biden administration (2021-2024). There is also significant seasonal patterns to RFE Rates under the Trump administration, with the lowest RFE rates in May which climbs steadily, peaking in Q4 (October-December): With Trump back in office in 2025, immigration attorneys are already reporting a return to these stricter adjudication patterns . Combined with Trump’s public statements promising to reduce work visa approvals and prioritize American workers, the surge in RFEs we’re seeing at The Build Fellowship isn’t surprising — and is likely to intensify throughout 2025 and beyond. Why Do Applicants Receive RFEs? USCIS issues RFEs for a variety of reasons, but most boil down to one thing: the initial petition didn’t provide enough clear, convincing evidence to satisfy eligibility requirements. Common Triggers for RFEs What Does an RFE Look Like? Explanation of the Issue: USCIS explains exactly what they believe is missing or unclear in your original filing. Specific Evidence Requested: This might include degrees, work samples, letters of support, financial documents, or legal clarifications. Response Deadline: Usually, applicants get 87 days to respond, but the timeframe can vary. Step-by-Step Guide to Responding to an RFE Here’s how to approach an RFE strategically to give yourself the best chance of approval: 1. Read It Thoroughly — and Break It Down Go through the RFE line by line. Highlight key requests and create a checklist so nothing gets missed. 2. Gather Documents (and Extra Evidence) Don’t just send the bare minimum. The goal is to overwhelm USCIS with clarity — think of it like answering every possible follow-up question before they even have to ask. 3. Organize Your Response Use a clear, labeled format with a cover letter explaining how each document addresses the specific issue raised in the RFE. 4. Consult with an Immigration Attorney This is especially important if the RFE raises legal or technical questions. If you need a trusted lawyer, our vetted network of immigration attorneys can connect you with experienced experts who understand employment-based immigration inside and out. 5. Respond Early Never wait until the last minute. USCIS must receive the full response before the deadline — not just a postmark date. Tips for Avoiding RFEs Table Special Considerations for H-1B Applicants H-1B petitions, especially for tech roles, are a prime target for RFEs . This is largely because: USCIS frequently questions whether the job truly qualifies as a specialty occupation . Roles that are generic-sounding (like "analyst" or "consultant") are more likely to trigger RFEs. If the employee works offsite (such as at a client site), USCIS may demand proof of employer control over daily tasks. What Happens if You Ignore an RFE? This part is critical: Ignoring an RFE almost always leads to denial. Even if the request seems unfair or unnecessary, you need to respond thoroughly and on time. If you miss the deadline, USCIS will treat the petition as abandoned and deny it outright. Can You Get More Than One RFE? Yes, especially in complex cases . After responding to the first RFE, USCIS can issue a second RFE if new questions arise. This is more common in cases involving: Complex employer-employee arrangements (like staffing agencies). Questions about degree equivalency for specialized roles. Concerns about maintenance of status when switching between visa types. Conclusion: RFE Readiness Is Key in 2025 RFEs are no longer the exception — they’re becoming the norm under the Trump Administration . With a higher rate of petitions triggering RFEs in 2025 , thorough preparation and proactive documentation is essential to keeping your immigration journey on track. Lastly, if the H-1B lottery didn’t go your way — you can obtain a cap-exempt H-1B as a Build Fellow . We’ve helped countless foreign nationals stay employed , navigate RFEs smoothly without relying on the lottery altogether by working with cap-exempt universities. You can also check out our fellows' success stories to see how this unique program has transformed real careers. Share: About the author Daniel Kwik is the Director of Marketing & Technology at The Build Fellowship where he guides foreign nationals in their immigration journey and remains a passionate advocate for opening opportunities for them in the US. Prior to The Build Fellowship, Daniel founded Sojon , a grassroots initiative to curate H-1B cap-exempt jobs for thousands of international students and foreign nationals. Main Content: A Complete Guide to the H-1B Amendment Process: When and How to File – The Build Fellowship Blog immigration-tips H-1B RFE (Request for Evidence) Rates Are Climbing Under Trump February 24, 2025 | 5 min read A Complete Guide to the H-1B Amendment Process: When and How to File Daniel Kwik, Director of Marketing & Technology Table of Content A Complete Guide to the H-1B Amendment Process: When and How to File What Triggers an H-1B Amendment? Change in Work Location: Change in Job Duties or Promotion: Salary and Working Conditions: Corporate Restructuring: How to File an H-1B Amendment File a New Labor Condition Application (LCA): Key Considerations for Employers and Employees Frequently Asked Questions About H-1B Amendments Maintain Compliance with The Build Fellowship Conclusion Share: A Complete Guide to the H-1B Amendment Process: When and How to File The H-1B visa program is highly regulated, with specific rules on maintaining employment terms that align with the original visa petition. When significant changes, known as "material changes," occur in an H-1B employee's job, such as relocation, a shift in responsibilities, or a promotion, an amendment may be required to ensure compliance with U.S. immigration law. This guide will explore the scenarios where an H-1B amendment is necessary, how to file one, and why timely updates are critical for maintaining lawful status. What Triggers an H-1B Amendment? H-1B amendments must be filed for material changes in an H-1B holder's job. This includes: Change in Work Location: If an H-1B worker relocates to a worksite outside the metropolitan statistical area (MSA) specified in the original Labor Condition Application (LCA), an amendment is required. For example, moving from New York City to San Francisco would require an amendment since wages, working conditions, and compliance factors vary significantly across regions. Short-term placements (up to 30 days, or 60 days in some cases) outside the MSA may be exempt, but documentation must still align with USCIS standards for compliance​. Change in Job Duties or Promotion: If the core job responsibilities shift substantially—such as a software engineer promoted to a managerial role—an amendment is necessary. The new role must still qualify as a "specialty occupation" under H-1B requirements, and updated qualifications must be documented​. Salary and Working Conditions: Substantial salary increases, reduced hours, or modified job conditions that alter the original employment terms also require an amendment. This is crucial for maintaining wage compliance as stipulated in the LCA​. Corporate Restructuring: When an employer undergoes major corporate changes like mergers or acquisitions, an amendment may be necessary to inform USCIS of the updated employer details, ensuring that employment remains compliant with H-1B terms​. How to File an H-1B Amendment File a New Labor Condition Application (LCA): File a New Labor Condition Application (LCA): The employer must submit an updated LCA with the Department of Labor (DOL) for the new location or job role. The LCA ensures that wages and conditions meet regional requirements. Submit Form I-129: After the LCA is certified, the employer files an amended Form I-129, including the new LCA and any supporting documentation. This form is critical for notifying USCIS of the material changes and aligning the H-1B worker’s status with updated employment details. Premium Processing Option: If expedited processing is desired, employers can file Form I-907 alongside I-129 for premium processing, reducing USCIS review times from months to around 15 days, which is especially useful for time-sensitive relocations​. Key Considerations for Employers and Employees Timing and Compliance: Ideally, the amendment should be filed before the employee begins working under the new terms or at the new location. If immediate relocation is necessary, filing the amendment as promptly as possible is advisable to maintain compliance and avoid penalties​. Consequences of Not Filing: Failing to file an amendment for material changes can result in severe repercussions, including loss of H-1B status for the employee and potential fines or restrictions for the employer. USCIS may conduct site visits to verify compliance with filed amendments. Impact of Amendment Denial: If an amendment is denied, the employee can continue to work under the terms of the original petition, provided the location or duties revert to the original state. Employers should consult with immigration counsel to determine the best course of action following a denial​. Frequently Asked Questions About H-1B Amendments Maintain Compliance with The Build Fellowship At The Build Fellowship, we offer cap-exempt H-1B solutions designed to assist foreign national employees with an alternative pathway to maintain their work status in the U.S., without relying on the H-1B lottery. Our fellowship program is a concurrent, cap-exempt employment solution in partnership with universities, enabling international professionals to maintain their H-1B status without dependence on the H-1B cap. With the Build Fellowship program, foreign nationals have the opportunity to lead industry projects for five hours per week, which allows their main employer to file a concurrent, cap-exempt H-1B petition. This can be a strategic solution for professionals facing frequent relocations or changes in job duties that typically trigger H-1B amendments. To explore if our program is the right fit for you, learn more about the fellowship on our program page . Conclusion Filing an H-1B amendment is essential whenever there are material changes in employment, such as job location or role. Ensuring compliance with USCIS regulations can safeguard both employees and employers from penalties and potential status issues. By understanding the amendment process and maintaining accurate records, employers can keep their workforce legally compliant, and H-1B employees can stay focused on their professional growth in the U.S. An immigration pathway to train the future U.S. workforce The Build Fellowship offers a powerful solution for foreign nationals who were not selected in the H-1B lottery, but want to continue working in the U.S. Through our partnerships with nonprofits and universities, we enable fellows to work in part-time cap-exempt H-1B roles while retaining their primary employment. Prior to The Build Fellowship, Daniel founded Sojon , a grassroots initiative to curate H-1B cap-exempt jobs for thousands of international students and foreign nationals. Main Content: Ultimate H-1B Visa Timeline Guide 2025-26: Step-by-Step Process and Key Deadlines – The Build Fellowship Blog immigration-tips H-1B RFE (Request for Evidence) Rates Are Climbing Under Trump February 7, 2025 | min read Ultimate H-1B Visa Timeline Guide 2025-26: Step-by-Step Process and Key Deadlines Daniel Kwik, Director of Marketing & Technology Table of Content Overview of the H-1B Visa Process Timeline Step 1: Employer Preparation (October – December) Step 2: H-1B Registration Period (March) Step 3: H-1B Lottery Selection (March – April) Step 4: Petition Filing Period (April – June) Step 5: USCIS Processing (June – September) Step 5: USCIS Processing (June – September) Alternative Timeline and Pathways for Skilled Foreign Workers through Cap-Exempt H-1B Visas: Summary Share: The H-1B visa allows foreign nationals to work in specialized fields in the United States, such as IT, finance, engineering, and health care. This visa requires both meticulous planning and adherence to strict timelines, as applications must be submitted within defined windows and are subject to a lottery system due to high demand. USCIS has announced the lottery dates for 2025-2026, and we’ve broken this down in the article. Here’s a breakdown of each phase in the H-1B visa process, important dates, and a look at alternative options available for those who don’t secure an H-1B visa through the standard cap. Overview of the H-1B Visa Process Timeline Step 1: Employer Preparation (October – December) This early phase is critical for employers to prepare and finalize details to ensure that they can submit a compliant H-1B registration and petition. Candidate Identification: Employers assess workforce needs and identify potential H-1B candidates. This includes reviewing each candidate's qualifications to ensure they meet the requirements for specialty occupation status. Specialty Occupation Determination: Employers should confirm that the job position qualifies as a 'specialty occupation,' a term that USCIS defines as a role typically requiring a bachelor's degree or higher in a specific field. Document Collection: Employers gather necessary documentation, including the candidate's educational credentials, prior work experience, certifications, and any other materials that demonstrate their suitability for the role. Collecting and verifying these documents in advance prevents delays later. Budgeting and Planning: Employers should budget for potential H-1B application fees and consider whether they may want to use premium processing later in the application. Step 2: H-1B Registration Period (March) The H-1B registration period is a mandatory step and is conducted entirely online. USCIS Online Registration: During this phase, employers submit basic information about the company and the employee they wish to sponsor. For the 2025-26 season, the registration window was open from March 7 to March 24, 2025. Each employer account can submit multiple applications if sponsoring multiple employees. Confirmation and Submission: Once registration is submitted, USCIS will issue a confirmation for each candidate, which the employer should save for future reference. Step 3: H-1B Lottery Selection (March – April) If the number of registrations exceeds the annual cap, USCIS conducts a random selection process or “lottery” to determine which candidates will proceed to the next phase. Annual H-1B Cap: The standard H-1B cap is 65,000 visas, with an additional 20,000 visas for applicants holding advanced degrees from U.S. institutions. Lottery and Selection Notification: After the registration window closes, USCIS typically conducts the lottery in late March. Employers will receive notifications through their online account if their candidates have been selected by early April. Next Steps for Selected Candidates: Employers of selected candidates can begin preparing to file a complete H-1B petition (Form I-129) with supporting documents. For historical lottery selection results and insights, check out our article here . Step 4: Petition Filing Period (April – June) This is the phase where selected H-1B candidates officially submit their petitions to USCIS, with the goal of demonstrating that both the employer and the employee meet H-1B requirements. Labor Condition Application (LCA): Employers must file a Labor Condition Application (LCA) with the Department of Labor (DOL). The LCA outlines salary and working conditions to ensure the H-1B employee will be compensated fairly. The DOL typically takes about seven days to process the LCA, so it's best to file early. Form I-129 Submission: Once the LCA is certified, employers can submit Form I-129 (Petition for a Nonimmigrant Worker) to USCIS, along with the certified LCA, documentation of the employee's qualifications, and proof that the role qualifies as a specialty occupation. USCIS usually provides a filing window of 90 days from April 1. Fees and Optional Premium Processing: Filing fees vary, and employers can choose to use premium processing, which costs an additional $2,500. With premium processing, USCIS will review the petition within 15 calendar days. Step 5: USCIS Processing (June – September) Once the H-1B petition is filed, it moves into USCIS processing, where officers review the submission and make a decision. Standard Processing: Regular processing can take several months, depending on USCIS's workload. During this time, USCIS may issue Requests for Evidence (RFEs) if more documentation or clarification is needed. Premium Processing (Optional): Employers who paid for premium processing will receive a decision within 15 calendar days. This can be helpful if the employer and candidate need to know the outcome sooner, though it does not affect the ultimate start date of October 1. Approval or Denial Notification: USCIS will notify the employer of approval or denial. Approved candidates receive an I-797 Notice of Action, which is necessary for employment authorization. Step 5: USCIS Processing (June – September) If the petition is approved, the candidate can begin working in their H-1B role as of October 1, the start of the fiscal year. Employment Authorization: The I-797 Notice of Action allows the employee to begin work in the United States legally under the H-1B visa status. Travel and Visa Stamping (If Abroad): For H-1B employees currently residing outside the U.S., the final step is to schedule a visa interview at a U.S. consulate. Once the visa is stamped, they can enter the U.S. and begin employment. Alternative Timeline and Pathways for Skilled Foreign Workers through Cap-Exempt H-1B Visas: The regular H-1B visa timeline is restricted by specific application windows and subject to annual caps, which often leave highly qualified foreign nationals without a visa due to the lottery system. However, there is a different category of H-1B visas known as cap-exempt H-1Bs , which allow for applications to be submitted year-round, irrespective of the annual cap. Here’s a closer look at how cap-exempt H-1Bs work and how they offer a flexible alternative for foreign nationals and employers. Key Differences of Cap-Exempt H-1B Visas Year-Round Application: Unlike the regular H-1B, which can only be filed in the designated period in March, cap-exempt H-1B petitions can be filed at any time throughout the year. This flexibility allows both foreign nationals and their employers to pursue visa sponsorship outside of the restrictive annual timelines. No Lottery Process: Cap-exempt H-1Bs are not subject to the annual 85,000 visa cap (65,000 for general applicants and 20,000 for U.S. advanced degree holders). As a result, there's no lottery process, reducing the uncertainty and enabling qualified foreign nationals to secure a visa without having to rely on chance. Eligibility Requirements: Cap-exempt H-1B visas are generally limited to specific types of employers, including: Institutions of higher education (universities and colleges) Non-profit organizations affiliated with universities Non-profit research organizations Government research organizations How The Build Fellowship Leverages Cap-Exempt H-1Bs for Foreign Nationals For foreign nationals who were not selected in the H-1B lottery or need to obtain an H-1B outside of the typical application windows, The Build Fellowship offers an innovative solution . By partnering with cap-exempt universities, The Build Fellowship enables fellows to work part-time leading students, allowing them to qualify for a cap-exempt H-1B. Here’s how this process works and how it benefits both fellows and their employers: Cap-Exempt Sponsorship through University Partnerships: The Build Fellowship works with H-1B cap-exempt universities, which means foreign nationals who join as fellows are eligible for a cap-exempt H-1B leading students on specialized industry projects. Concurrent Employment with Full-Time Employers: Once a Build Fellow obtains the part-time cap-exempt H-1B, their primary employer can file a full-time concurrent H-1B without going through the lottery — meaning the fellow can work full-time at a private company under the cap-exempt visa, without needing to wait for the next lottery. Ideal for High-Demand Situations and Flexible Hiring: Cap-exempt H-1Bs provide immediate hiring flexibility, which is crucial for companies with pressing project deadlines or hard-to-fill roles. Since The Build Fellowship operates outside the annual H-1B timeline, companies that need to bring in foreign talent on short notice, or whose candidates were not selected in the lottery, can still secure skilled employees through this alternative path. Long-Term Stability for Foreign Nationals: For foreign nationals, The Build Fellowship provides a pathway to sustained employment without the uncertainty of the lottery. Fellows gain the added benefit of contributing to higher education through leading industry projects while advancing their professional careers in the U.S. By using The Build Fellowship’s cap-exempt model, both employers and foreign national employees gain increased control over the H-1B process, reducing the risks and timelines associated with the traditional cap. If you’re interested in learning more about how The Build Fellowship has helped foreign nationals continue their employment without lottery dependence, check out our success stories from fellows or explore ongoing projects with cap-exempt university partners. Summary The H-1B visa process follows strict timelines and annual caps, often leaving many skilled foreign nationals without a visa due to the lottery system. This guide covered each stage, from preparation through petition filing, plus cap-exempt H-1Bs —an ideal, flexible alternative for employers like universities since they can be filed year-round without the lottery. Through The Build Fellowship’s cap-exempt solution , foreign nationals can work part-time with partner universities, enabling their primary employers to file a concurrent cap-exempt H-1B for full-time employment without lottery restrictions. This unique pathway provides stability for foreign professionals while meeting companies' hiring needs outside the standard H-1B constraints. Main Content: Applying for an H-1B Visa Extension: Step-by-Step Procedures & Costs – The Build Fellowship Blog immigration-tips H-1B RFE (Request for Evidence) Rates Are Climbing Under Trump February 3, 2025 | 4 min read Applying for an H-1B Visa Extension: Step-by-Step Procedures & Costs Michael Cruse, Immigration Program Co-Director Table of Content Types of H-1B Extensions 1.Initial H-1B Extension (Up to 6 Years) 2. Extensions Beyond the 6-Year Cap Eligibility Requirements Required Documents for H-1B Extension Filing Process and Timeline Standard Process Premium Processing 240-Day Rule Fees for H-1B Extension Traveling During the H-1B Extension Process H-1B Extension Denials and Next Steps Conclusion Share: The H-1B visa, central to the U.S. employment visa system, allows professionals in specialized fields to work in the United States for up to six years in two three-year terms. However, many visa holders seek extensions beyond this timeframe, especially if they are in the process of securing a green card. In this guide, we’ll explore everything you need to know about H-1B visa extensions, eligibility requirements, processes, fees, and the best strategies for a smooth extension process. Types of H-1B Extensions 1.Initial H-1B Extension (Up to 6 Years) The H-1B visa, central to the U.S. employment visa system, allows professionals in specialized fields to work in the United States for up to six years in two three-year terms. However, many visa holders seek extensions beyond this timeframe, especially if they are in the process of securing a green card. In this guide, we’ll explore everything you need to know about H-1B visa extensions, eligibility requirements, processes, fees, and the best strategies for a smooth extension process. 2. Extensions Beyond the 6-Year Cap Under the American Competitiveness in the 21st Century Act (AC21), H-1B visa holders can qualify for one-year or three-year extensions beyond the six-year limit if: They have an approved I-140 petition but cannot apply for a green card due to per-country limits or priority date backlogs; or They have a pending labor certification (PERM) or I-140 petition filed at least 365 days before the end of their six-year term​. Eligibility Requirements To qualify for an H-1B extension, an applicant must: Be employed in a specialty occupation by a U.S. employer. Have maintained lawful H-1B status, as evidenced by payroll documentation, I-94 records, and employment verification. If applying for a post-six-year extension, meet the specific AC21 conditions mentioned above​. Required Documents for H-1B Extension When preparing to file for an H-1B extension, gather the following essential documents: If extending beyond six years under AC21, include the I-140 approval notice or evidence of a pending PERM application to show eligibility​. Filing Process and Timeline Standard Process Filing Timeline : Employers can submit an H-1B extension petition up to six months before the visa expiration date. This early filing helps avoid gaps in employment eligibility. Processing Time : Standard processing generally takes 4 to 6 months, though it can extend up to 12 months in some cases​. You can check the latest at the USCIS case processing times page . Premium Processing For an additional $2,805, premium processing guarantees a response from USCIS within 15 calendar days. This option is recommended if the expiration date is near, as it prevents employment disruption during the extension period​. 240-Day Rule If an extension petition is filed before the visa expires, the visa holder may continue working for up to 240 days beyond the expiration date while waiting for a decision. However, travel outside the U.S. is discouraged during this period, as it can complicate the application​. Fees for H-1B Extension Traveling During the H-1B Extension Process While waiting for extension approval, avoid international travel if possible, as it can delay the process or lead to issues re-entering the U.S. Once the extension is approved, travel is generally permitted; however, you may need a new visa stamp to re-enter the country. A recent Department of State pilot program may soon allow H-1B holders to renew visa stamps from within the U.S., but this is still in the experimental stage​. H-1B Extension Denials and Next Steps Common reasons for extension denials include: Missing or incomplete documentation Employer-employee relationship issues Lack of evidence for continued specialty occupation status In case of a denial, USCIS typically provides a reason and may allow for an appeal or a Motion to Reopen (MTR). Consulting with an experienced immigration attorney can be beneficial in preparing documentation or assessing alternative options, such as filing a new petition with a different employer. Conclusion Successfully navigating an H-1B extension requires thorough documentation, timely application, and strategic planning. By understanding eligibility requirements, maintaining careful records, and preparing well in advance, H-1B holders can ensure a smoother path to securing their visa extensions. An immigration pathway to train the future U.S. workforce The Build Fellowship offers a powerful solution for foreign nationals who were not selected in the H-1B lottery, but want to continue working in the U.S. Through our partnerships with nonprofits and universities, we enable fellows to work in part-time cap-exempt H-1B roles while retaining their primary employment.
